issue.body:
Resolves: #5390

- [x] I signed [CLA](https://www.audacityteam.org/cla/)
- [x] The title of the pull request describes an issue it addresses
- [x] If changes are extensive, then there is a sequence of easily reviewable commits
- [x] Each commit's message describes its purpose and effects
- [x] There are no behavior changes unnecessary for the stated purpose of the PR

Recommended:
- [x] Each commit compiles and runs on my machine without known undesirable changes of behavior

QA :
- [x] Doesn't re-introduce https://github.com/audacity/audacity/issues/5313
- [x] If a clip has no trimming, rendering is with RMB or with mix-and-render command yields bit-exact result
- [x] Whether stretch-rendering a clip and then applying an effect or directly applying the effect yields bit-exact result
- [x] All the above was done in mono and stereo
- [x] Test tracks with other sample formats than float
- [x] Test with a non-trivial envelope and observe the correct placement of points on the timeline
- [x] Cut lines are NOT preserved.  Whether this is agreeable to design will be decided later.

issue.title: When trimming, first snapping interval doesn't snap

labels.name: bug
labels.description: An error, undesired behaviour, or missed functionality

issue.body:
### Bug description

_No response_

### Steps to reproduce

1. generate chirp of 6.5 seconds long
2. enable snapping to seconds
3. using the trim handle, slowly start dragging the right edge of the clip leftwards
4. observe

### Expected behavior

The clip doesn't get trimmed until the 6.0s time mark is reached. Then, clip snaps to it.

### Actual behavior

Before reaching the nearest snapping point, i.e. the 6.0-second time mark, the clip can be trimmed freely, as if snapping was turned off.
When trimming further, snapping behaves as expected.

https://github.com/audacity/audacity/assets/70063970/b0ee3fed-f4a0-42cd-b171-fd3250a4f35b



### Audacity Version

current master / alpha / nightly build

### Operating system

Windows, macOS

### Additional context

_No response_

issue.title: v3.1.3 - crash on Windows IME switch
issue.body:
Hi, noob here.
Audacity freezes when switching language input via the in-built Windows 10 IME.
It may just be Chinese input.  Or it may be the act of switching itself.

The whole program becomes unresponsive,
and switching back to English input doesn't fix it.
Terminating the program and opening it up again in English input does the trick.

comment.body: The problem still exists, when I try to save an audio file, it crashes even in japanese ime A mode, I lost all my work in half an hour...

issue.title: Bar formats: there can be more digits for than needed

labels.name: bug
labels.description: An error, undesired behaviour, or missed functionality

labels.name: regression
labels.description: Bug is a regression against previous version

issue.body:
### Bug description

_No response_

### Steps to reproduce

1. Open Audacity
2. Change the format of selection start to bar:beats
3. Open selection settings menu, and choose start and length of Selection.

### Expected behavior

Selection length: 000 bar 00 beat

### Actual behavior

Selection length: 00000 bar 00 beat

### Audacity Version

latest beta

### Operating system

Windows

### Additional context

_No response_

issue.title: Drag and drop of (previously exported) label files

labels.name: Enhancement Request
labels.description: Or feature requests. Open-ended requests are better suited for discussions.

issue.body:
### Your idea

When using label tracks to annotate audio files in Audacity, you can export your labels and then re-import them by using File → Import → Labels…
It would be super useful if you could simply drag and drop a label file onto Audacity, as you can do for audio tracks.


### Problem to be solved

If you're using Audacity for annotating sets of audio files using label tracks, you need to switch a lot between different files.
Typically, each audio file (say "recording001.wav") has a corresponding label file ("recording001.txt").
And each time you switch to a new pair of audio/label files, you currently need to do this:
1. remove all tracks (or start a new Audacity instance)
2. drag and drop the audio file on Audacity (or go through the File menu)
3. go to: File -> Import -> Labels (3 clicks) and then browse for and select the label file to import

It would be nice if you could also drag and drop a previously exported label file onto an open Audacity project.
Then you could simply select the both the audio and label file in Windows Explorer / macOS Finder / ... and drar and drop them both on Audacity instead of having to go through the menu each time.

The drag and drop handling could check the file extension (.txt), and then add the labels as a new label track in the project.
Since .txt is a not-so-specific and rather common extension, the drop event handling could do some quick contents check first (like checking the first line and see if it is pure text with 3 tab-separated columns).

Also, if you drag and drop _set_ of audio files and label files, they would all be added as audio tracks and label tracks.


### Prior art

_No response_

### Additional context

Was originally discussed here on the Audacity forum some time ago: https://forum.audacityteam.org/t/drag-and-drop-of-previously-exported-label-files-fr/65174/1

pull_request.title: Power buttons dirty the project (even if only restoring prior state)
pull_request.body:
Resolves: #4151

A simple change so that pressing the power button of an effect list or a
single effect causes the nag to save the project when you close the window.

But this also causes the warning without need if you press the button twice,
toggling back to the original state.

issue.body:

comment.body: @Paul-Licameli Sorry for unsolicited pinging, but it appears this PR has fallen off everyone's radar, and I was wondering what it would take to get this to land. Not sure if the PR author is up for amending fixes, but I'd be happy to lend a hand where possible.

commits.message:
Add a set of patches to better support OpenBSD and FreeBSD

- When dlopening libraries on OpenBSD we need to drop the major version
- OpenBSD does not have sys/timeb.h. Note this has been removed from POSIX.1-2008
- Correct the mistake with the FreeBSD symbol, it should be __FreeBSD__

pull_request.title: Add a set of patches to better support OpenBSD and FreeBSD
pull_request.body:
```
- When dlopening libraries on OpenBSD we need to drop the major version
- OpenBSD does not have sys/timeb.h. Note this has been removed from POSIX.1-2008
- Correct the mistake with the FreeBSD symbol, it should be __FreeBSD__
```
